title: Subradiant CBS
text: This webpage reproduces some preliminary results of my research, for my own learning experience, and maybe future students will benefit from this notes too.

title: 1  General Expressions
text: We will follow Rouabah et al. (2014), but our analysis will be limited only for the Scalar Model.

title: 1  General Expressions
text:
1.1 Scattered Field
Given an essemble of atoms at positions \(\textbf{r}_j\), the radiation field, \(E(\mathbf{r})\), measured at distance \(\mathbf{r}\) is
\[
    E(\mathbf{r}) = -i\frac{ħ \Gamma}{2d}\sum_{j=1}^N G(|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_j|)\tilde{\beta}_j
\]
We also assume multiple-scattering events, that is, the excitation \(\tilde{\beta}_j\) is a result of excitation of all other atoms, in addition to a pumped constant inicident field \(E_{in}(\mathbf{r})\), creating a recursive expression:
\[
E(\mathbf{r}) = \kappa (\delta) \sum_{j=1}^N G(|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_j|)\left [ E_{in}(\mathbf{r}) +  \kappa (\delta) \sum_{j=1}^N G(|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_j|) E_{in}(\mathbf{r}_m) \right ]
\]
where \(\kappa (\delta) = 1/(2i\delta - 1)\) and \(\delta = \Delta/\Gamma\). The term in brakets we will be
\[
    \tilde{\beta}_j = \frac{2d}{ħ \Gamma}\kappa (\delta) \left [ E_{in}(\mathbf{r}) +  \kappa (\delta) \sum_{j=1}^N G(|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_j|) E_{in}(\mathbf{r}_m) \right ]
\]
The constants will play a role later to simplify further expressions
The notation and its meaning, are not clear ye (?)t.

title: 1  General Expressions
text:
1.2 Dynamics
The scattering over time results from obtain \(\beta_j(t)\)
\[
E(\mathbf{r}, t) = -\frac{\hbar \Gamma}{2d}\sum_{j=1}^N G(|\mathbf{r} -  \mathbf{r}_m|)\beta_j(t)
\]
We get the \(\beta_j(t)\) with the Coupled Dipole time evolution WITHOUT LASER (?):
\[
\frac{d\beta_j}{dt} = (i\Delta-\Gamma/2)\beta_j  - (\Gamma/2)\sum_{m \ne j} G(|\mathbf{r}_j -  \mathbf{r}_m|)\beta_m
\]
Since this equation is linear, its solution is an exponential of form:
\[
\beta_j(t) = i\frac{2d}{\hbar \Gamma}b_j(t)e^{(i\Delta-\Gamma/2)t}
\]
This formula allows us to simplify our problem, and solving \(b_j(t)\) means:
\[
\frac{d b_j}{dt} = - (\Gamma/2)\sum_{m \ne j} G(|\mathbf{r}_j -  \mathbf{r}_m|)b_m
\]
Putting everything together, the scattering becomes:
\[
E(\mathbf{r}, t) = e^{(i\Delta-\Gamma/2)t}\sum_{j=1}^N G(|\mathbf{r} -  \mathbf{r}_m|)b_j(t)
\]
with
\[
    b_0 = \kappa (\delta) \left [ E_{in}(\mathbf{r}) +  \kappa (\delta) \sum_{j=1}^N G(|\mathbf{r}_j-\mathbf{r}_m|) E_{in}(\mathbf{r}_m) \right ]
\]

title: 1  General Expressions
text:
1.3 Intensity
To keep analytical tretament, we need to define \(E_{in}(\mathbf{r})\) and \(G(|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_j|)\), for convenience, we take

\(E_{in}(\mathbf{r}) = E_0 exp(i \mathbf{k_0} \cdot \mathbf{r})\)
\(G(|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_j|) \approx exp(ikr - i \mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_j)/(ikr)\)

\[
E(\mathbf{r}, t) = \frac{e^{ikr + i\Delta t - \Gamma t/2}}{ikr}\sum_{j=1}^N e^{-i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_j}b_j(t)
\]
\(\mathbf{k} = r\hat{r}\)
with
\[
    b_0 = \kappa (\delta) E_0 \left [e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_j} +  \kappa (\delta) \sum_{j=1}^N G(|\mathbf{r}_j-\mathbf{r}_m|) e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_m} \right ]
\]
The scattered intensity is
\[
I(\mathbf{k}, t) = \frac{1}{(kr)^2}e^{-\Gamma t} \left |  \sum_{j=1}^N e^{-i \mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_j} b_j(t)\right |^2
\]

title: 1  General Expressions
text:
1.4 Expanding the Intensity
Suposse that \(N=2\), and expand the expression. We will see that it has a usefull pattern - I am want to write down an example for clarity purpose.
We begin by noticing that the sum is a complex number, therefore its absolute value is \(|z|^2 = z \cdot z^*\). For two atoms one reads:
\[
\begin{alignat*}{4}
I(\mathbf{k}, t) &= \left |  e^{-i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1}b_1(t) + e^{-i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2}b_2(t) \right |^2\\
&= \left [  e^{-i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1}b_1(t) + e^{-i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2}b_2(t) \right ]\left [  e^{+i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1}b^*_1(t) + e^{+i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2}b^*_2(t) \right ]\\
&= b_1(t)b^*_1(t) + e^{-i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1}b_1(t)e^{+i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2}b^*_2+ e^{-i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2}b_2(t)e^{+i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1}b^*_1(t) + b_2(t)b^*_2(t)\\
&= |b_1(t)|^2 + |b_2(t)|^2 + b_1(t)b^*_2(t)e^{-i\mathbf{k}\cdot (\mathbf{r}_1 - \mathbf{r}_2)} +  b_2(t)b^*_1(t)e^{-i\mathbf{k}\cdot (\mathbf{r}_2 - \mathbf{r}_1)}\\
\end{alignat*}
\]
In general, we can infer that:
\[
I(\mathbf{k}, t) = \frac{1}{(kr)^2}e^{-\Gamma t} \left [  \sum_{j=1}^N |b_j(t)|^2 + \sum_{j \ne m}^N b_j(t)b_m^*(t)e^{-i\mathbf{k}\cdot (\mathbf{r}_j - \mathbf{r}_m)} \right ]
\]




Rouabah, Mohamed-Taha, Marina Samoylova, Romain Bachelard, Philippe W. Courteille, Robin Kaiser, and Nicola Piovella. 2014. “Coherence Effects in Scattering Order Expansion of Light by Atomic Clouds.” J. Opt. Soc. Am. A 31 (5): 1031–39. https://doi.org/10.1364/JOSAA.31.001031.

title: 2  Two-Atom Approximation
text:
\[
    \begin{alignat*}{4}
    \frac{db_1}{dt}&= -(\Gamma /2) G_{12}b_2\\
    \frac{db_2}{dt}&= -(\Gamma /2) G_{21}b_2\\
    \end{alignat*}
\]
To solve the system we do a varible substitution:
\[
    \begin{alignat*}{4}
    x &= b_1 + b_2\\
    y &= b_1 - b_2\\
    \end{alignat*}
\]
and using the fact that \(G_{12} = G_{21}\), we begin our manipulation:

For \(x\):

\[
    \begin{alignat*}{4}
    \frac{db_1}{dt} + \frac{db_2}{dt}&= -(\Gamma /2) G_{12}b_2 + -(\Gamma /2) G_{12}b_1\\
    \frac{d(b_1 + b_2)}{dt} &= -(\Gamma /2) G_{12}(b_2 + b_1)\\
    \frac{dx}{dt} &= -(\Gamma /2) G_{12}x\\
    x(t) &= x(0)e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}
    \end{alignat*}
\]

For \(y\):

\[
    \begin{alignat*}{4}
    \frac{db_1}{dt} - \frac{db_2}{dt}&= -(\Gamma /2) G_{12}b_2 - -(\Gamma /2) G_{12}b_1\\
    \frac{d(b_1 - b_2)}{dt} &= +(\Gamma /2) G_{12}(b_1 - b_2)\\
    \frac{dy}{dt} &= +(\Gamma /2) G_{12}y\\
    y(t) &= y(0)e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}
    \end{alignat*}
\]
We solved \(x,y\), but I want \(b_1, b_2\). The inverse operation is:
\[
    \begin{alignat*}{4}
    x &= b_1 + b_2\\
    y &= b_1 - b_2\\
    x + y &= 2b_1\\
    b_1 &= \frac{1}{2}x + y\\
    \end{alignat*}
\]
Hence:
\[
    \begin{alignat*}{4}
    b_1(t) &= \frac{1}{2}x + y\\
    b_1(t) &= \frac{1}{2}[x(0)e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} +  y(0)e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}]\\
    b_1(t) &= \frac{1}{2}\{[b_1(0) + b_2(0)]e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} +  [b_1(0) - b_2(0)]e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}\}\\
    b_1(t) &= \frac{1}{2}[b_1(0)e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} + b_2(0)e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} +  b_1(0)e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} - b_2(0)e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}]\\
    b_1(t) &= \frac{1}{2}[b_1(0)e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} +  b_1(0)e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} + b_2(0)e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} - b_2(0)e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}]\\
    b_1(t) &= \frac{1}{2}\{b_1(0)[e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} +  e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}] + b_2(0)[e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} - e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}]\}\\
    \end{alignat*}
\]
Now we use the formula for \(b_j(0)\)
\[
    \begin{multline*}
    b_1(t) = \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 \left [e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1} +  \kappa (\delta) \sum_{m \ne 1}^N G(|\mathbf{r}_1-\mathbf{r}_m|) e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_m} \right ][e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} +  e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}]  \\
    + \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 \left [e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2} +  \kappa (\delta) \sum_{m \ne 2}^N G(|\mathbf{r}_2-\mathbf{r}_m|) e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_m} \right ][e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} - e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}]
    \end{multline*}
\]






Important



In the manuscript there is a negative sign, “-”, in from of second line, regarding the second atom. As I just proof, there is no negative sign in the intermediary steps
How come up with the “-”?








Important



The sum \(\sum_{m \ne 2}^N G(|\mathbf{r}_2-\mathbf{r}_m|) e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_m}\) for example has just a single term \(G(|\mathbf{r}_2-\mathbf{r}_1|)e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1}\), because \(N=2\)
Why do we write the sumation?


One last manipulation, to put single-atom and multi-atom term’s together

Single-Atom Terms

\[
    \begin{multline*}
     b_1(t)^{single-atom} = \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 \times e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1} \times [e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} + e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}]\\
     + \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 \times e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2} \times [e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} + e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}]\\
    \end{multline*}
\]
\[
    \begin{multline*}
     b_1(t)^{single-atom} = \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1} e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} + \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1}e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}\\
     + \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2} e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} + \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2}e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}\\
    \end{multline*}
\]
\[
    \begin{multline*}
     b_1(t)^{single-atom} = \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 (e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1} - e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2})e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}+  \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 (e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1} + e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2})e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}
    \end{multline*}
\]

Two-Atom Terms

This time, we don’t want to expand the terms.






Note



I’m writng the single term of the sum, \(G_{12}\), because I want to discover how far I can go.


\[
    \begin{multline*}
     b_1(t)^{two-atom} = \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 \times \kappa (\delta) G_{12} e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2} \times [e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} + e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}]\\
     +\frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 \times \kappa (\delta) G_{12} e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1} \times [e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} - e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}]
    \end{multline*}
\]
\[
    \begin{multline*}
     b_1(t)^{two-atom} = \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta)^2 E_0 G_{12} \{ e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2} [e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} + e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}] + e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1} [e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} - e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}]\}
    \end{multline*}
\]
Final expression is:
\[
    \begin{multline*}
     b_1(t) = \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 (e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1} - e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2})e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}+  \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta) E_0 (e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1} + e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2})e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}\\
     + \frac{1}{2}\kappa (\delta)^2 E_0 G_{12} \{ e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_2} [e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} + e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}] + e^{i\mathbf{k}\cdot \mathbf{r}_1} [e^{-\Gamma /2 G_{12}t} - e^{\Gamma /2 G_{12}t}]\}
    \end{multline*}
\]
